thread.title: Outback windmills go solar on Red Centre cattle station
thread.title_full: Outback windmills go solar on Red Centre cattle station

author: Katrina Beavan
title: Outback windmills go solar on Red Centre cattle station
text:
Windmills are iconic symbols on many outback cattle stations, but that look is changing in parts of central Australia. 
At Undoolya station, just outside of Alice Springs, windmills are being replaced with solar panels. 
Ben Hayes said he started thinking about making the switch almost 15 years ago. 
"We've just been taking the gear out of the windmill and putting solar pumps down, building my own solar array and the frames. 
"I found them so much more efficient, and a lot easier to handle." 
Mr Hayes said the time was right to ramp up the installations. 
"The technology and the price of them has come back so much it is a given that you might as well do it," he said. 
"I'm having a good season [with] good prices so I might as well put some bucks back into the property." 
"I like to get it up and going and do those sorts of things while I can." Photo: A rare mono windmill stands tall on Undoolya station alongside new solar panels. (Supplied: Undoolya Station) 
Mr Hayes said everyone on the station was supportive of the modernisation. 
"I just like them for the ease of maintenance on them. The only thing that worries me is we're running electricity into water and we've always been told not to. 
"That's a concern, I don't understand that yet but I'll get my head around that and once I do I'll be right. Solar power offers new opportunities 
He also see the versatility of the solar units for other things. 
"You can go there and if need be you can hook a generator up to them, fire them up in the evening. It can run all night until you've run out of fuel, and you don't have to go back the next day and flick any switches. It will automatically flick into solar for you, which is great for me so far." 
Mr Hayes said the most recent one he had pulled out was an old mono windmill, which was very rare. 
"You don't see too many of them around. 
"The mill is still there, and I pulled the mono gear out and just replaced it with the solar." 
He said some of the mills he had been taking out would date back to the late 40s and early 50s which his grandfather put up. 
"With some of them we've been cutting down and dropping on the ground and cutting them up and using the steel into yards and stuff. 
"And it just seems bloody strange coming up to a bore with no mill there anymore — you'd nearly get lost" 
The station hopes to change all the windmills to solar eventually, as well as other aspects of the property. 
"I've got my auto drafting for drafting my steers — that's running on solar. 
"I'm actually toying with the idea of making a bugle yard with automated drafting in it running on solar panels. I'm thinking of different things to use solar for," Mr Hayes said. 
"I also wouldn't mind trialling a calf cradle that runs on solar, electric over hydraulic using solar, so we're trying different things."
